textRegions.text: WTF: Syllabus reviewed and expectations set.
LOL: Chat it up. Ask me anything.
OMG: Do something you [probably] don’t know how to do.
Build your own server from scratch.
EC2 = Elastic Cloud Computing. Basically a computer in the cloud.
S3 = Simple Storage Service. Basically a hard drive in the cloud.
Everything Else = We’ll deal with it on a case by case basis.
Sign up for Amazon and log into the portal.
Step 4: Make a group like this
Click Instances. I’m not giving you a screenshot for this one. C’mon.
wait what step are we on?
Launch an instance by clicking the “Launch Instance” button
Create a new “Key Pair”. Name it whatever and download it.
Set the server to “Ubuntu Server 12.04 LTS”, 64-bit (my
Click “Edit Details” on the next screen.
Remember when we made that security group? Yeah, click that.
We need to open Terminal.app for this.
Windows users - Putty and WinSCP - http://bit.ly/1YXodh
ssh = log into the server but on the command line. Think FTP.
ubuntu is automatic default username for a new EC2 Ubuntu server.
Your command line is connected to your EC2 server.
Until you disconnect (Ctrl+D) you are on that machine.
Always do this whenever you launch a new instance.
An Ubuntu “package manager”. Install stuff on your server super fast.
It’s like Finder for the WWW. It’s the engine behind > 100 million web sites.
sudo = super user “do”. sudo means that the computer is your bitch.
You need permission to sudo. In this case Amazon pre-configured it.
apt-get = the command line program to run, our package manager
install = what we want the program to do. Bet you can guess this one.

sudo apt-get install php5 php5-dev libapache2-mod-php5 php5-curl php5-gd php5-idn php-pear php5-imagick php5-imap php5-mcrypt php5-memcache php5-ps php5-pspell php5-recode php5-snmp php5-tidy php5-xmlrpc php5-xsl php5-common
Google “apt-get install [name of thing you’re trying to install]”
-m creates a home directory for that user.
You’ll need to enter the password twice. It won’t show up on the screen.
Type “i” to begin editing. (i as in insert)
Set port from 22 to 30000. This is for security.
You can restart lots of services with this.
Whenever you change a config file you probably need a restart.
Set up the WWW directory so we can edit it.
You did it. You built a server from scratch.
ls -la = list files a little bit more organized
chmod permissions dirOrFile = change the read/write permissions. complicated.
chown user:group dirOrFile = change the owner of a file. also complicated
Ctrl+D or Ctrl+C usually quits something. I always forget which is which.
Apple+T creates new tabs. Useful for having one remote connection and one local.
i = insert. once in insert mode type as normal.
(aside: Larry Tessler invented Word Processing because he hated vi)
Ruby is a very popular platform these days. Perhaps install that?
Or perhaps you want an all JavaScript solution. NodeJS + MongoDB.
I know some of you are Django and Python nuts. Go on... Google it. You know you want to.
Linux geek and hate Ubuntu? That’s fine. Use another flavor. You won’t hurt my feelings.
Terminate your server and rebuild it from scratch. Practice makes perfect.
If you screw up you can always terminate and restart. If that even costs you a penny I’d be shocked.
Build and deploy a small web site that takes some part of this deck and translates it into HTML, CSS and JavaScript. Hit me with your best shot.
